I am  concerned about l2fprod dependency. I don't see this artifact in a public Maven repo : http://search.maven.org/#search|ga|1|l2fprod (though there are similarly named jars) . If you think the new library is worth inclusion in Cayenne, could you please share your thoughts on Cayenne dev@ mailing list?

[Cayenne pull requests #75](https://builds.apache.org/job/Cayenne%20pull%20requests/75/) SUCCESS
This pull request looks good

Got Jira and the pull request the moment I sent my related message to dev :) Thanks for the patch. Will wait a few days and then merge it. Will also need to revisit our JDBC connection management code - there may be some crutches that we kept for Java 7 compatibility. As well as update the docs.

Thank you. Searching for "Java 7" and "JDBC 4.1" leads to quite a lot of matches.

for cleaning the commits
Just committed it with some squashing. So I think you could close this pull-request manually.
Just [opened a Jira](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAY-2044) and merged the PR. Thanks!

I just tried running the modeler with these changes. I like how the new UI for reverse engineering looks. However I wasn't able to reengineer my test MySQL DB. When I tweak reengineering XML and click "execute", nothing happens. Is this still something we need to finish?

We need to review code and make some tests. Also we have some things to discuss with Alex. So I think it is not the final commits. But hope we are close. We are applying it on the next week.

Anyway, looks strange that it doesn't work :( 
We will investigate and fix it.
Andrus, please, check now if it is working ok or not. The bug was fixed, I think.
Great.

Just merged the PR. The hack in `QueryAssemblerHelper` wrapping null in `new DbAttribute("null")` is no longer needed, as I cleaned up those meaningless unit tests. 

Before we close CAY-2050 , let's try to start using the new API per second part of the Jira: "refactoring of other related methods, such as DbAdapter.bindParameter(..), which will be significantly simplified".
The changes have been applied. This pull request can be closed now.

I wonder if we can generalize over ParameterBinding, SQLParameterBinding and ProcedureParameterBinding and avoid 3 `DbAdapter.bind...` methods? After all the calling code  cares about the following properties:
- Object value
- int statementPosition
- int jdbcType
- int scale
- column name (logger only)
- ExtendedType (logger in the future)

All (most?) of the calls to `getAttribute()`, etc. are simply bad encapsulation in the current code.

Also, can we rename the pull request to CAY-2050? Cayenne Jira can not make sense of the current name, and can't automatically detect that this PR is about CAY-2050.
Had to touch a lot of classes. I hope it won't damage public API.
This pull request is now merged.
This is now merged to master.
@ollybondareva, thanks. I have merged these commits with several code formatting improvements. You can close this pull request now.
Has been done by https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAY-2051
I have just created a JIRA  [issue](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CAY-2064) and merged this pull request. Thanks.
@alexei-grigoriev : could you please close the pull request? I committed your branch after a local rebase, so GitHub didn't recognize that your changes are already in.
Fix applied . see my comment under CAY-2066. Feel free to close this PR
Nice, thanks!

Hi @lonvarscsak Thanks for your contribution.

I'm not really sure the usefulness of this addition is worth the extra clutter in this class. Can you assume that the user will always want an ArrayList?
I applied the patch. We already have symmetrical static methods in the Ordering class. The new ones make sense to me.

Hey Ari, sorry for not responding sooner.  Personally I find it very useful.  I find myself writing the same thing over and over and breaking up my variable declarations to do so, and this simplifies this.

I used ArrayList because Cayenne makes this assumption pretty much everywhere.  But in reality I'm not declaring it as an ArrayList, so you can't make an assumption it's any specific List implementation.
I closed the parent Jira. Not a bug. Let's close the PR please.

Analyzing this some more, I think the fix should be different. Instead of cleaning the String from special chars, we should simply pass any objects whose encoding is not immediately clear as parameters to formatter String:

``` java
throw new CayenneRuntimeException(""No cached list for %s", serverMetadata.getCacheKey())
```
Just merged it with some additions so you could close this one.
Has been implemented by 34646fd5baf3640208399b2f21afc7afff6def51
re: c7ae3e1eef487452b9be908ec1d76c247c58a27d Good catch! I meant to change this, but forgot.

@atomashpolskiy also see 30a7b53556ad8db41d0909bf27c57d1ea4782e55 ... We have 2 identical maps of converters now.. Don't remember why we did it this way. Perhaps we'll need to merge them. But for now each converter needs to be added in 2 places.
Can we please add license headers and also change reference to Integer.BYTES (that requires Java 8) to something else. E.g. Integer.SIZE / Byte.SIZE
Sorry, did not know that Integer.BYTES was added in 1.8

- [ ] Complete RE tutorial by adding more examples for reverseEngineering configuration file, types mapping, etc.
- [ ] Add docs for Modeler Reverse Engineering
- [ ] Add references/links through the docs
- [ ] Final review

One suggestion - instead of treating injectable collections as "extras", add all the standard types to them as well when creating Crypto Module. So whatever is passed to DefaultValueTransformerFactory, is the final set of converters, and there's no merge step inside DefaultValueTransformerFactory.
@andrus , PR updated
Merged, thanks!
Nice! Wondering why do we need this profile declaration in submodules (cayenne-server, cayenne-client). Regular postgres profile is only declared at the top level. This seems to be sufficient.

Yes, it works when putting the "executions" to the parent pom. However then the Postgres Docker container would be started and stopped for each submodule, even for those that don't have any integration tests and don't need a running database. This would slow down the build by 2-5 seconds per module. As the two submodules run tests against a database I choosed that approach. But feel free to change.

PS: The pull request is result of discussion here: https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/206a60fb8697c2bc1b7c9c44f62f9eb6a7500bb9a6b57b3bd70ebaac@%3Cbuilds.apache.org%3E
Ah, good point. Our current Docker-free profiles don't need to start anything. So they are simpler.

Unfortunately, there is a problem to use it on mac https://github.com/fabric8io/docker-maven-plugin/issues/430

Anyway, I'll check it on Linux soon and I'll add configurations for other databases.

Thanks!

Thanks for the PR. I am +0.

I wouldn't use this API for queries, as the alternative of attaching to the query directly is easier:

``` java
ObjectSelect
     .query(Person.class)
    .orderBy(Person.COMPANY_NAME.asc(), Person.FIRST_NAME.desc());
```

Though I guess it may be useful for building in-memory ordering sequences. 

A few notes on the code:
- We need the Apache license header on the new OrderingsClass
- I wouldn't subclass ArrayList though. Rather hide it inside the Orderings class for cleaner encapsulation
- We need unit tests...

Anyone else has thoughts on this?

I took this discussion to the dev list to ensure everybody sees it:
https://lists.apache.org/thread.html/81091880b3e8a64302f5f3b1a67cd706b60f157c3ae48ccda4e8e0e4@%3Cdev.cayenne.apache.org%3E

My other consideration is Java 8 Comparator interface already has chaining functionality. So Orderings seems redundant now, isn't it?

I think the `orderBy(...)` syntax is easier and cleaner (at least to me), plus subclassing `ArrayList` feels a tad wrong to me since `ascs` returns a concrete implementation now instead of an interface.  Admittedly this is a personal opinion.  There are also Java 8 specific things (`Property<>` vs `Property<Object>`) which shouldn't be in cayenne-server.  I think I'd lean more towards a -1 on this one, but need to evaluate it more.

I get it, you all hate meI understand. ;)

The ArrayList is to be compatible with other APIs that expect a List of
Ordering.  Im curious why returning an implementation is really any
different than what ascs() does today.  I get that the user is hidden from
the implementation deal, but both return ArrayList.  I pretty much always
use SelectQuery which takes a List<Ordering>.

I didnt realize I had Java 8 stuff in there, thats my mistake, Id
correct if this was going any further. :P

The Java 8 Comparator stuff I hadnt considered (since Cayenne is not Java
8), but youre right, that might work just fine.  Ill give that a whirl
and see if it meets my needs.

-Lon

Thanks a lot for your pull-request!

I already merged it by https://github.com/apache/cayenne/commit/23eb17ed5448618fd444625551479c25979f5ccc, but I did something wrong and pull-request wasn't closed automatically. Sorry about that. 

Could you close this PR, please?

My fault, but commit a851bb6 also needs to be merged.  Thanks!

Thank you for the pull-request.

Oh darn I though all the tests were run as part of package, hadn't tried install. Sorry about that, I'll try to find out what's happening.
Just wrote a test per CAY-2143 . The problem is reproducible. I broke this recently when refactoring reverse-engineering code. Thanks for the fix.
The tests are split into "unit" and "integration" (those with IT suffix). ```mvn test|package``` execute unit tests, while ```mvn verify|install``` execute both unit and integration.
@stariy95 : I did a rebase instead of merge by mistake. Could you please close this PR by hand. The code is already on master.

Very neat. I very much like the result of the refactoring.
Another good one. My only request is a formality - can we annotate all the new / renamed public classes with "@since 4.0" tag.
Thank you for review! Sure I'll review all new public classes and annotate them.
